posts.name: Mohammed
posts.cooked:
As the title suggests, why would teams still opt for the Limelight 3G (aside from financial reasons) when newer and more capable alternatives exist?

The following reason I’m saying this is because:-

Limelight 4 offers superior AprilTag detection and pose estimation compared to the LL3G.

Limelight 3 + Limelight 4 allows for object detection, but LL3G alone lacks Coral USB Accelerator support.

I mean based on these points, it really seems like LL3G is becoming less practical for optimal usage in 2025, Not to mention that there was a one year gap between LL3G (WHICH WAS RELEASED MID COMP) and LL4 which was really a waste of money for the teams who bought LL3G. (my opinion)

Am I missing any key advantages of using the LL3G? Would love to hear other perspectives!

posts.name: Lexeo
posts.cooked:
4272 will be using 2 LL3Gs this season.

We are doing this because we have been testing them for a full off-season and since week 1 in a kitbot (before the LL4 was released). We have things working the way we want them to.

We don’t think so he increased frequency from going to the LL4 is worth learning and testing something new. There are also risks/bugs with new hardware, and we don’t want to be the ones learning about those in the field. If we find a limitation where the LL4 would be helpful, we might switch, but so far the 3G is fine.

That said if you are looking to buy something new today, with no experience, the LL4 is a good choice. Its not worth it to try and find a used 3g (other than for financial reasons).

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor

posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked: We bought 2 of them after last year’s season and spent a lot of time in the offseason working with them and learning what we felt we needed to.  Had no idea they’d already be obsolete 6 months later.  We have no money left to buy LL4 so we’ll be rolling with the 3G.
Every single limelight has been sold essentially since our team knew what a limelight was, so we would use whatever limelight we could get our hands on.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Mohammed:

Would love to hear other perspectives!

I think this is an awesome question, and points to some things that are different in ‘real-world’ engineering from FRC .

In FRC , an annual “forced-reset” of a new game causes a lot of teams to practice what I would call “white paper” or “green field” engineering - IE, you have great capability to start from scratch, bring your previous knowledge to bear, and “get things right”.

In the real world, it’s much more common to need to carry-over engineering work from previous years. The opportunity to start a project fully from scratch is much less frequent. Re-doing “working” designs is often not the right answer from a total cost perspective.

That being said, most FRC teams will see at least some of this “carryover” due to having parts on hand from previous years, and working codebases. Even more now that the rules changed, to allow more prefabricated components.

These are broad brush strokes.

But here’s how I see it, flip your question around: Presume that you have a working localization setup using Limelight 3G’s. What exactly is the reason to switch?

The key is that assumption that current setup works . As long as that does, adding better hardware has no impact on the “change L’s to W’s” metric.

Now, let’s say you instead take that same time and effort and put it into updating to new LL hardware, and put it into automating some tricky tasks for the driver in teleop. That does have some potential to decrease cycle time.

Again, assuming my LL3G setup works sufficiently for my needs, the engineering answer should be to invest in the latter (teleop automation), not different limelights.

posts.name: Michael Jansen
posts.cooked:
Mohammed:

Limelight 4 offers superior AprilTag detection and pose estimation compared to the LL3G.

In its current state, not really. You’ll get better FPS but that’s really not that important for localization. The internal IMU drifts so much that you end up getting worse estimates by the end of the match than if you just used your robot IMU, which would be functionally identical to the 3G but with higher FPS.

This might change with the next update, but without a solid ETA we’re not counting on it.

Mohammed:

Limelight 4 allows for object detection, but LL3G alone lacks Coral USB Accelerator support.

Sorta the same thing here, not really in its current state in any way that’s much better. The LL4 also doesn’t support coral, and they have no plans to release a hailo compatible model with the next update according to their changelog. Converting a model for a hailo on your own is a massive pain as far as I know. I don’t know if any community member has actually done it yet. So for object detection you’re really limited to CPU models or a LL3 + coral.

Basically, I wouldn’t call the 3G obsolete just yet. If you have them, you won’t really gain anything from upgrading right now.
